editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The INTRODUCTION.
div.p: AS Black as my Ceremony-monger is, (here de≈øcrib'd) he is neither Moor, nor Tawny-Moor, Infidel nor Jew; but a Prote≈øtant-profe≈ø≈ø'd; he may be a Papist, or wor≈øe (an Athei≈øt) in Ma≈øquera ‚Ä¢ e, but his Face is Prote≈øtant.

I grant, that I have Cen≈øur'd, Condemn'd, and Hang'd him up in Effigie; yet I have drawn no Blood, done hurt to none; for my Man is a Man of Clouts, a Man in the Clouds, a meer Individuum Vagum; ≈øo that no Man alive can be offended, becau≈øe let his Guilt be never ≈øo great, in being like my Whiffler-Eccle≈øis≈øtical, though ‚Ä¢ e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ip him to the very Heart, and fly in ≈øo much influance the Throne, come thither, and make him blu≈øh, yet he is as ≈øate as a Thief in a Miln, except he come into Court, and confe≈øs him≈øelf to be the Man which is here (for his guilt) Expo≈ø'd and Sentenc'd.

If the Fool Confe≈øs, he mu≈øt Suffer, like that ≈øilly Wit-all, (who ≈øhal he namele≈øs) and not being content to be a Cuckold, he mu≈øt needs Wind his Horn, and Proclaim his own ≈øhame in open Court, by good Evidence; and ≈øo he remains a Cuckold upon Record; like the ≈øilly Snall, who had never been taken for a Cornudo, or Horn'd-Brute, if he him≈øelf had not thru≈øt out his own Horns: If ≈øuch Di≈øa≈øters behappen a Wi≈øe Man, his Wi≈øe≈øt way is to make no Words on't, but to cover the ≈øhame as decently as may be, and put his Horns in his Pocket.

This Brute with his Irrational Ceremonies, ≈øhould belong to a Prote≈øtant Church and Con≈øtitution; but (like an out-lying Deer, which are u≈øually the ‚Ä¢ u≈øtie≈øt and fatte≈øt of all the Bruti≈øh Herd) has through Wantonne≈øs, or greedy Ravage, broke out of the Pale of the Church; where if he would be content to keep, „Äà‚óä„Äâ would be ≈øafer for him; and my de≈øign is (in pure Love and Kindne≈øs to his Welfare) thus gently to Hunt him Home; and ≈øo he will acknowledge it ≈øurely: But what Gratitude can a Man in Rea≈øon expect from a Brute, who hears no Rea≈øon, but is guided by furious Pa≈ø≈øion and Appetite?

And I deny not, but that he may owe much of the Fle≈øh on his Back ‚Ä¢ o his Rambling after Popi≈øh like Ceremonies, (when Popery did ≈øo much influance the Throne, in the happy days of the two Ca≈øtle-mains, and Fa
‚Ä¢ her Peter) who not being able to bring in Popery Bare-fac'd, therefore the Quid pro Quo, the ≈øomething like it, and near it, mu≈øt be countenanc'd ‚Ä¢ d preferr'd. And my Ceremony-Monger is now as loth to depart with ‚Ä¢ em, (his Dear dear, Silly, and Illegal Ceremonies) for old Acquain
‚Ä¢ nce-sake, as with his old Dog, or old Hor≈øe, that though pa≈øt Service, yet ‚Ä¢ e retains them for old Kindne≈øs, and old done Deeds.
And yet they are ≈øuch, as neither the Laws of God nor Man ever made, ‚Ä¢ d therefore mu≈øt be Condemn'd and Executed, if brought to the Bar of ‚Ä¢ ly Writ, and right Rea≈øon.

At which Bar, no Man has a better Commi≈ø≈øion of Oyer and Terminer, to ‚Ä¢ raign and Judge him, than my ≈øelf, as being lawfully (into the Sacred ‚Ä¢ der of Prie≈øt-hood) Ordain'd, and the Holy Bible then put into my ‚Ä¢ nds, by the Learned Saunder≈øon,) then Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, and now (I ‚Ä¢ bt not) a Saint in Heaven, though he was Nick-nam'd the Presbyterian
an Bi≈øhop, and of a Captain, (both per≈øwaded me, and) made me a Prie≈øt, ≈øaying, Take thou Anthority to preach the Go≈øpel.

There's my Commi≈ø≈øion; and let any Man, Pope or Bi≈øhop, ≈øhew a patent more Authentick to Teach all Nations; and I will never Preach nor Writ Divinity hereafter; but there are but very few Glergy-Men, or Bi≈øhops in England, (either in or out of the Univer≈øities) that can ≈øhew any Authority of ≈øo ancient Standing, or of to old a Style and Date as mine. Nay, we had no Scripture, if Writing be not Preaching: Be≈øides, if I ≈øhould not thus teach my Ceremony Monger by the Pre≈øs, I could not Admoni≈øh him at all; for my Pulpit is a narrow place, though it ≈øtand alo≈øt; and few Ceremony-Mongers de≈øire to be cured. For ‚Ä¢ ike men that have filthy old Ulcers on their Legs, they hate to be dre≈øt before folks; they had rather It ≈øhould Fe≈øter, than be known. There is not one word in the Ordination of Bi≈øhops, in our Common-Prayer-Book, or in Holy Writ, that gives a Bi≈øhop more Authentick Orders to preach, than a Presbyter or Prie≈øt; only the King's Maodate makes him the King's Commi≈ø≈øioner: But in reference to God or the People, a Bi≈øhop has no better or fre≈øher Character to Teach, or Admini≈øter the Holy Sacraments, than any Pre≈øbyter, or than him≈øelf; whil≈øt he was but Pre≈øbyter; Nor has any King or Parliament, Bi≈øhop, or Synod, any Power, any lawful Power to ≈øilence me for teaching Truth: The Character is Indelible; when they an≈øwer what I have Writ, concerning Imprimatur's, or Re≈øtraint of the Pre≈øs (in my late Speech without Doors) they ≈øhall hear further from me.

For no Fle≈øh alive has more Authority than our Lord Je≈øus, and the Apo≈øtles had, which was for Edification, not De≈øtruction; to do good, not harm; to Advance, not to Depre≈øs Truth; to ≈øave Mens Lives, Liberties and Properties, not to de≈øtroy.

But ≈øome may object to me, that the late King did ≈øilence me, ≈øhut me out of my own Pulpit, and bani≈øh't me from my Hou≈øe and Home, my Self and my Family, for three or four years la≈øt; not only again≈øt Law, Equity and Con≈øcience; but without Law or any Colour, Proce≈øs or Form of Law; and yet I ≈øubmitted in quietne≈øs and ≈øilence, and made no noi≈øe in the World, nor to the World; not ≈øo much as Groaning or Complaining, but far down ≈øilently.

To which I an≈øwer, by confe≈ø≈øing that it is (all of it) a great Truth, and I was by Arbitrary Power and Oppre≈ø≈øion, to my Damage! ≈øome hundreds of Pounds, thus ≈øilenc'd (as a fore≈øaid) by Will and Plea≈øure: a word from the Court ejected me from my Pulpit and my Hou≈øe: but al≈øo a word from the Court recall'd me, about a month before the Dutch Landed.

To the Righteous God, I made my humble Appeal, and he heard in Heaven his dwelling Place, and laugh'd my Adver≈øaries to ≈øcorn, yea the Lord has had them in Deri≈øion; and tho≈øe that bani≈øh'd me from my Hou≈øe without Law, and without a Cau≈øe, are by God's Righteous Hand and Judgment, turn'd out of their Hou≈øes and Homes; and before they went, recanted their Oppre≈ø≈øion towards me; but going away in ha≈øte, his Apo≈øtles could not hear me Re≈øtitution for the inju≈øtice.

the≈øe Illegal Ceremonies in The Black Non-conformi≈øt ≈øeven years ago: The times would not bear i ‚Ä¢ , the Criminals would not hear; P ‚Ä¢ pery, & Popi≈øh-like Ceremonies were Rampan ‚Ä¢ , My Soul did weep in ≈øe ‚Ä¢ et for their Pride, they would not hear, the Judgments of God are beginning at the Hou≈øe of God. And have got a box o'th' Ear for my pains, (you mean) by that particular Application; whereas now none can be offended ju≈øtly, except his guilty Con≈øcience make him confe≈øs, that I have hit him home, and that he is the Man.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of Sureties in Bapti≈øm.
div.p: AND now, you may ≈øee by the Picture I have drawn, that a Ceremony-monger's Soul, and Con≈øcience is neither rul'd by Holy Scripture, Right Rea≈øon, nor by the Law of the Land; but in de≈øpight of all the≈øe, ≈øome of them are ≈øuch only through Cu≈øtom, Ignorance, blind Devotion, implicite Faith, and api≈øh Imitation; others, and tho≈øe no ≈ømall Fools, upon de≈øign, duckoy'd by Avarice and Ambition: But, Cu≈øtom is a ≈øecond Nature, even in Religion too, or more properly, Super≈øtition: Cu≈øtom is the Father, and Ignorance is the Mother of their Devotion: As ≈øoon may an Ethiopian change his Skin, or a Leopard his Spots, as a Ceremony-monger his foppi≈øh Super≈øtition, he is ≈øo accu≈øtomed to it. Cu≈øtom can beget nothing upon a Man of Rea≈øon, a Man who≈øe Rea≈øon is not clouded; and yet Cu≈øtom has a Brood in the World far more numerous, than Truth could ever beget; becau≈øe Truth, the Father of wi≈øe men, can never beget any thing, but upon Rea≈øon the Mother of true Devotion: But the≈øe Mothers are but few, and therefore there are but few of the Breed, very few rational Men, and rational Chri≈øtians, in compari≈øon of the Numbers of tho≈øe that go the broad Way, and go in at the broad Gate that leadeth to De≈øtruction; and many there be that go in thereat, namely, all tho≈øe, who≈øe Religion and Wor≈øhip has no other Ground, except Cu≈øtom (in Conjunction with Mother Ignorance) for their foppi≈øh Devotion; and Covetou≈øne≈øs, for their Knavi≈øh Super≈øtition.

Thus the poor ≈øilly naked Indians, In America, (I have catechized, them) and ask'd them the Rea≈øon, Why they did bow to ≈øuch an Idol, that was nothing more than other. Wood and Trees of which it was made: They had all one and the ≈øame An≈øwer, namely, Cu≈øtom, and their Peel's Peel's, What are they? but a certain crafty ≈øort of Men among≈øt them, that lead the re≈øt of the Fops by the No≈øe, by ≈øome Super≈øtitions of their own Invention, Peel's, that is, Prie≈øts of the Devil, whom they wor≈øhip in that ‚Ä¢ owing Idolatry! for they never wor≈øhip God, (whom they acknowledge in dark apprehen≈øion) for they ≈øay, God is good; and ≈øome of them will ≈øay. God is a good Man, and will not hurt them, and therefore they wor≈øhip the Devil to a≈ø≈øwage his mi≈øchievous Wrath.

Even ≈øo, our Engli≈øh foppi≈øh Ceremony-mongers an≈øwer, (when I catechize them) and ask them the Rea≈øon of their bowing to the Altar
when there is no Idol, and to the Ea≈øt when there is nothing Divine more than in the South and North, and the Altar nothing, but a piece of Wood, made of the ≈øame Wood and Trees with the Pues, the Stools and the Pulpit: then, ju≈øt like the naked Indians, that are but ju≈øt one degree (if they be ≈øo much) remov'd from a Monky, an≈øwer, that it is a Cu≈øtom and their (Peel's: or) Prie≈øts do ≈øo, and therefore the poor Apes imitate, that's all.

Oh! but the Prie≈øts are cra≈øty, and have ≈øome more Rea≈øon (though a wicked One) to bow to nothing; they do not bow for nothing, they get a Place by it, and Preferment; and therefore are forc'd to get as many Fools as they can to be their Di≈øciples and Followers; for, when Owles are alone, they are houted at, but not Birds that fly in Flocks, tho they be Jack-dawes.

I have ask'd ≈øome of them a Rea≈øon for their confus'd and profane. irrational and un≈øcriptural babling together the Reading P≈øalms! and all their An≈øwer is, that [It is granted, that) It is a confus'd Noi≈øe, and therefore unintelligible; but their prie≈øts do ≈øo, and the Singing Boys; and they are accu≈øtomed to it: It is a very hone≈øt Confe≈ø≈øion; but is this Man-like, or Baboon-like?

I have ask'd ≈øome account al≈øo, of others, how the Organs got into Church, to make ≈øuch a Noi≈øe, and at ≈øo great a Charge and Expence, In the fir≈øt purcha≈øe and continuance; Judas his Que≈øtion is proper here, To what purpo≈øe is this wa≈øte? Had they not better be ≈øold, and the Organi≈øt's Sellary retrench'd, and given to the poor?

They an≈øwer, that Mr. Alderman was willing withal, and that he could not ≈øtay a long Hour or two out of his Counting-hou≈øe, at Devotion, without ≈øleeping; and therefore, how clunch-fi≈øted ≈øoever he u≈øed to be at other times, yet on this occa≈øion he nimbly opens his Pur≈øe to pay the Mu≈øick, for that it either keeps him from ≈øleeping, or joggs and awakens him, and makes him ≈øtare and look up; therefore, &c. But of all the brisk Rea≈øons of my Ceremony-mongers, that of a She Ceremony-monger was very ≈øurprizing, when being ask't why ≈øhe, in defiance of plain Scripture, ≈øpoke in the Church, an≈øwered nimbly, That her Tongue was ≈øo u≈ø'd to wagg at home, that it could not lie ≈øtill in the very Church? and yet the ≈øame Church-pratter, was ≈øilenc'd, when que≈øtioned, why ≈øhe, in imitation of the Doctor's bowing his Noddle to the Altar, Madam Limberham made a Courte≈øy, and bow'd both her Knees? no Rea≈øon could be got for that Mimickry; that is no more like, than an Apple is like an Oy≈øter.

And all the Rea≈øon that ≈øome Bi≈øhope can give, why they ordain many times, rude, illiterate, unthinking Don's to the Pulpit, to teach others, and know nothing of the Matter, nothing of their own Knowledge, no Divinity is concocted or dige≈øted, and made their own, and in their Head and Heart, (the Body of the Law is dige≈øted by a Lawyer, before he is fit to come to the Bar; and the Body of Phy≈øick, by Phy≈øitians, before they are fit to feel the Pul≈øe, or be Licen≈øed).

His An≈øwer is, That he tru≈øt; to his Deacon, or Arch-deacon, by implicite Faith, He believes as the Arch-deacon tells him; and that the form and manner of ordaining Deacons, Prie≈øts, and Bi≈øhops, requires no more: well, it is well, 'tis very well an≈øwer'd, and mo≈øt Epi≈øcopally;

And why do you Confirm, and lay Hands ≈øuddenly upon ≈øo many ignorant Per≈øons that under≈øtand not one Article of Faith, nor can ≈øo much as ≈øay the Creed? The an≈øwer is, The Common-prayer Book requires no more than to believe oy Implicit Faith, the fitne≈øs of all that the Pari≈øh Prie≈øt ≈øays is fit, he mu≈øt take it for granted, and believe as the Prie≈øt believes, and ≈øee with other Mens Eyes; but that is the Fault (Brother!) of your Con≈øtitution, that obliges you no more Work and In≈øpection, than any Mortal can perform.

Be≈øides, where do we read (except in the Ma≈øs Book, and Common-Prayer Book) of ≈øuch a thing in Scripture, as Confirmation by a Bi≈øhop? That Scripture of little Children coming to Chri≈øt, and he laid his Hands upon them, and ble≈ø≈øed them, is, in the Common-Prayer Book, apply'd to infant Bapti≈øm, in the Office of Publick Bapti≈øm; and mo≈øt incongruou≈øly (too) for that purpo≈øe; for Je≈øus baptized none, neither Men, Women, nor Children, but his Di≈øciples did that; Nay, the great Apo≈øtle of the Gentlies went about confirming the Di≈øciples by ≈øound Preaching, but he baptized very few; one, or two, or three, he confeiles that he did baptize, and if he had baptized any more, he had forgo ‚Ä¢ ; therefore he did not make ≈øuch a bu≈øine≈øs of it in his own Per≈øon: And as for laying Hands upon any Children, or other, there is not the lea≈øt mention of any ≈øuch Matter. How came it then into the Church; I'le tell you:

Infants being not able to make a Confe≈ø≈øion or Profe≈ø≈øion of Faith and Repentance, which two are required of all per≈øons before they be baptized, (as ≈øaith the Church of England in her Doctrine Catechi≈øtical in the Common-Prayer Book, and ≈øo ≈øaid St. Augu≈øtine, but I believe neither of them).

But, becau≈øe that Infants, by rea≈øon of their tender Age cannot perform them; therefore they do perform th ‚Ä¢ by Proxy, „Äà‚óä„Äâ by „Äà‚óä„Äâ , becau≈øe the Sureties do promi≈øe (a wi≈øe Rea≈øon, for ‚Ä¢ i≈øes may be broken) they ≈øhall perform both Faith and Repentance, when they come to Age.

Ay! Here's a wi≈øe Rea≈øon for a Learned Church, and enough to make all Rational Men (that have not lo≈øt their Rea≈øon) be Anabapti≈øts, or, at lea≈øt, like Witches, to deny their Bapti≈øm ≈øo Infancy.

For all Promi≈øes and Vowes are either broken or kept, but the Promi≈øes and Vowes of God-fathers and God-mothers in infant Bapti≈øm, are ≈øeldom or never kept; but are broken Vows, and broken Bonds and Promi≈øes.

The Sureties Promi≈øe and Vow, that the poor In≈øolvent Child (that cannot ≈øpeak for it ≈øelf) ≈øhall when it can hear (for Faith comes by hearing) have Faith; and when it can ≈øpeak, and gets Wit, then it ≈øhall have Grace to confe≈øs and repent.

But, ≈øuppo≈øe the Child live to have Wit enough to be a Ceremony-monger; Had ever any Man or Woman of them the Grace to confe≈øs, recant and repent? And then the Promi≈øe of the Sureties is not worth more than ≈øome Lord's Promi≈øe, nor worth a Farthing.

Again, ≈øuppo≈øe the Child prove Deaf, or Dumb, or a Fool, the Sureties Vow they do not know what; nay, if it live to be hang'd, as many are for Thieves, Witches, Murderers; Hlow is the God-fathers and Godmothers Vow and Promi≈øe perform'd, when they vow'd and promi≈øed for poor Child in Bapti≈øm, that it ≈øhould for≈øake the Devil and all his Works, the Pomps and Vanities of this wicked World, and all the ≈øinful Lu≈øts of the Fle≈øh. 2dly, They vow and promi≈øe that Child ≈øhall believe all the Articles of the Chri≈øtian Faith; do they not break their Vow, If poor Child prove to be a sceptick, a Hobbi≈øt, or an Athle≈øt? 3dly, They vow that the poor Child ≈øhall keep God's Holy Will and Commandment, and walk in the ≈øame all the days of its Life; Do they not break their Vow, if, poor Child, for whom they ≈øwore a ≈øolemn Vow and Promi≈øe, in the pre≈øence of God, being an Oath, happen to turn Apo≈øtate, Papi≈øt, Mahometan, or Infidel, are not the Sureties all for≈øworn? And though they be, or be not, there's the mi≈øchief, no good can po≈ø≈øibly come of it, but that which is lucumbent upon Parents, and which Sureties ≈øeldom or never mind, namely, Chri≈øtian Education; and if ≈øo, they ≈øhould not Swear and Vow in the Child's Name, that the Child does or ≈øhall believe and repent; It is enough to promi≈øe good Education (if the God-fathers and God-mothers be barren, or old and pa≈øt Children; in ≈øuch ca≈øe, it is enough to „Äà‚óä„Äâ kind and careful of another Man's Child: But if they have Children of their own, or likely to have any, it is too much, becau≈øe Charity ≈øhould begin at Home. And therefore the ≈øaid Vow and Promi≈øe, is, but u≈øually like the common Di≈øcour≈øe of Hectors and Bullies; (I ≈øwear and Vow, they cry on all Occa≈øions) when they intend nothing; by Vowing and Swearing, but for≈øwearing; and adding a Lye to the Promi≈øe and Vow.
Fir≈øt, Then the Sureties promi≈øe that which no hone≈øt Man can hone≈øtly promi≈øe, who makes Con≈øcience of a Vow, becau≈øe he promi≈øes that which is impo≈ø≈øible for him to perform.

Secondly, If the In≈øolvent Child be bound by Sureties and good Bayl, if he leave them in the lurch, he wrongs them not, he gave them no ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øion, Power, Deputation, Authority, or Reque≈øt to promi≈øe and vow in his Name: And therefore that talk of a Vow in Bapti≈øm, it non≈øen≈øe, idle, and vain: How can a Man break a Vow, or a Bond that he never made; but his Sureties made it in his behalf; Ay, without his order, knowledge, care, or de≈øire: How is Child concern'd therein, any more than other Children in the World? I have to hear Non-≈øen≈øe, much more to preach it, except I were ≈øure, I was to preach to none but Fops, that ≈øwallow every thing that the Prie≈øt puts in their Mouth (like the Wafer God) without chewing.

Thirdly, Suppo≈øe another Man's Faith or Repentance (that has enough of both) for his own Salvation, and al≈øo Merits (called Works of Supererogation by the Papi≈øts) to ≈øpare, heaped up and running over, which the Saints departed, St. Bridget, St. Winifred, St. Francis, St. Ignatius Loyola, St. Coleman, &c. has left at their Departure, as a la≈øt Legacy to the Pope (as the Papi≈øts hold) Faith and Repentance enough to ≈øave all the Whores and Rogues in the World, to whom the Pope gives, no Sells, to any that has Money, and is willing to Buy.

But, ≈øuppo≈øe the Fool and his Money be ≈øoon parted, and a Man get nothing but Hell by another Man's Graces of Faith and Repentance, by relying thereon, as Church of England holds; then much more Non≈øen≈øe it is for Church of England, on ≈øuch idle and fal≈øe Principles, to talk of Faith and Repentance to be performed, (tho never ≈øo much promi≈øed to be performed) by Proxy, or by Sureties.

Fourthly, Suppo≈øe (which is po≈ø≈øible) that the Sureties are In≈øolvent and have not Faith and Repentance for them≈øelves, then all this great Fat is in the Fire; they can never perform nor pay a Debt for another, that have not wherewith to di≈øcharge their own Debts, let them promi≈øe, and vow and be Bound in as many Bounds as they plea≈øe for other People; any Fool or Beggar can promi≈øe to pay a Thou≈øand pounds for another, but what ≈øignifie Promi≈øes, Vows, or Oaths, made only to be broken and for≈øworn?

Lastly, Which is the ≈øadde≈øt Ca≈øe of all, (or not a Pin to chu≈øe) ≈øuppo≈øe that poor Child is baptized without Sureties, as are the greate≈øt number by far, in this populous own; and in private Bapti≈øm, neither Sureties, nor the Sign of the Cro≈øs is required; then they mu≈øt bring Sureties afterwards to Church, and then it ≈øhall be ≈øigned with the Cro≈øs. div.head: CHAP. II. Of E≈øcapes in the Common-Prayer-Book, in reference to the Act of Uniformity.
div.p: WHat! ≈øhall we have no Ceremonies at all then? It is very ≈øtrange that Chri≈øtians will not be content with the Impo≈øition and Acts of Uniformity, which God, the Holy Je≈øus and his Apo≈øtles have provided. Ha≈øt thou Faith (≈øaith the Apo≈øtle) have it to thy ≈øelf? We have general Rules, as to honour God with our Sub≈øtance, or E≈øtates, in Works of Charity, which is the greate≈øt Thing in Religion, and without which all thy Faith and Hope is nothing, as ≈øaith St. Paul; or is a dead Carrion, as ≈øaith St. James, becau≈øe Charity, the Soul of Faith, is de ‚Ä¢
ed, when thou evidences thy Faith to be a nothing Faith, a dead Faith, by de≈øtroying Charity, in killing and impri≈øoning thy Brother for Faith's ≈øake; and perhaps thy weak Brother, for whom Chri≈øt died, through thy Impo≈øition, and Penal Acts of Uniformity; Acts that are not only mi≈øchievous in breaking the Peace and Unity of the Brethren, not only uncharitable in beating thy Son, or thy Brother, becau≈øe he is blind; re≈øtore him to his Sight, in the Spirit of Meekne≈øs, is the Apo≈øtle's Rule, blows will never cure his Blindne≈øs.

Be≈øides, Uniformity is an unnatural, impo≈ø≈øible, and therefore an irrational, wicked, and vain attempt: Go, teach God to make a new Heaven, with Uniformity of Stars, and Skies ≈øpangled uniformly, they are now all of different Forms and Features: Go, reach him to make Men uniform, they are all now of different Forms and Features; Go teach him to make a new Earth, and ≈øet a new Face on it; The Landskip now looks ≈øo much the more lovely by the Variety, which God and Nature ≈øeems to delight in; And wilt thou (thou ≈øilly Ceremony monger, and Projector) be wi≈øer than God?

If thou had≈øt ≈øeen our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour ≈øometimes ≈øtand and pray, ≈øometimes kneel and pray, ≈øometimes ly on a Bed or Couch, and eat the Holy Supper; ≈øometimes fall on his Face and pray; if thou had≈øt ≈øeen this variety, thou would≈øt have Excommunicated him, then capla≈øs'd and jalled him, if thy fiercene≈øs had not kick't him, and ≈øpurn'd him up, had≈øt thou but had an Act of Uniformity to back thee.

We are bound to honour God with our Sub≈øtance, In Works of Charity (the greate≈øt Duty) but how much; when, and how, in particular, is left to the di≈øcretion and liberty of every Man, no rule of Impo≈øition is, or can be made about it.

We are obliged to honour God with our Bodies, the lea≈øt thing in true Wor≈øhip, for bodily Exerci≈øe profiteth little, but how much, when, and how in particular, is le≈øt to the di≈øcretion and liberty of every Man, no Rule of Impo≈øition is or can be made about it.

Then, you'l ≈øay, the Church of England was mi≈øtaken in one of her XXXIX. Articles, that ≈øays, The Church has power to appoint Ceremonies: And al≈øo the King and Parliament were mi≈øtaken in the Act of Uniformity, that enjoint all Bi≈øhops and Clergy-men, on pain of Deprivation, to ≈øub≈øcribe, a≈ø≈øent, and con≈øent to all and every thing, as true, which is contained in the Common-Prayer Book.
Here is a heavy Charge, Convocation-Hou≈øe, and Parliament-Hou≈øe, both upon my back; but, come, one at once, and I'le deal with them both, one after another, as well and as fa≈øt as I can.

Fir≈øt then, I ≈øay, in general, that any Decree under Heaven, that is either unlawful, or Impo≈ø≈øible to be obeyed, is not at all Obligatory: This is ≈øo plain, that it needs no further Proof, it is like the Light of the Sun, ≈øelf-evident; if the Sun ≈øhine, no man doubts it, but he that is blind, or
winks on purpo≈øe, le≈øt he ≈øhould be convinc'd. And as to that Article, viz. The Church has power to enjoin Ceremonies‚Äîit confounds all the Ceremony-mongers among≈øt us. And in all my Travels, Reading, and Di≈øcour≈øes, I never met with any Man; Bi≈øhop, Prie≈øt, or Lay-man, that ever did, could, or dur≈øt explain what is there meant by Church.

If it be taken for the Clergy, either in (or out of) Convocation, or Synod, viz. That they have of them≈øelves a Jus Divinum, a Divine Right, to enjoin Ceremonies to the People of England, they all incur a Praemunire, that claim ≈øuch a Power, and ju≈øtly, for they there by ≈øet up a Legi≈ølative power, independent of, and di≈øtinct from the King and Parliament, (the only Legi≈ølators) and is of mo≈øt pernicious Con≈øequence, and found to be ≈øo in all Ages; And by the Statutes of Provi≈øors, made both by Popi≈øh and Prote≈øtant Kings and Parliaments, condemn'd as mo≈øt pernicious and in≈øufferable, by invading the only Legi≈ølative power, [Kings, Lords, and Commons] the great Fundamental of our Government, and ≈øetting up a Thing called, A Church, independent of, and equal with, or above the State, and bearding the State, if it be ≈øo bold as not to plea≈øe them, or ≈øhould dare to di≈øplea≈øe them. Better it is, not to be a State, than to be ≈øuch a pitiful State, at this precarious rate, that dare not but be Prie≈øtridden: Our Noble Ance≈øtors, in Popi≈øh Times, ≈øcorn'd the motion, and were true Engli≈øh Men: This di≈øtinction of Church and State, is a Popi≈øh and pernicious di≈øtinction; two higher powers is one too much.

But if by the Church in that Article, be meant, the King and Parliament, the Repre≈øentatives of the whole Body of the people, the Convocation and Canon-makers will by no means acknowledge that; for that makes them Cyphers, and [as many people account them] u≈øele≈øs Tools: And never did King and Parliament, neither, make Laws coercive in matters of Religion, or Uniformity in Religion, but Confu≈øion, Divi≈øions, Schi≈øms, Tumults, Sedicion, Blood, Ruine, and civil Wars, were the di≈ømal con≈øequences in England; whereas there would be none of the≈øe, no di≈ø≈øentions, no penalties, no complaining in our Streets, if the Legi≈ølative power, un≈øuborned by Prie≈øt-craft, make no Laws but what are proper for their cognizance, and for the peace, welfare, good manners, and good abearing in the State: And then, where there is no Law, there can be no Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion; and tho≈øe odious Names of Di≈ø≈øention and Sedition, Conformi≈øt and Nonconformi≈øt, will find an eternal Grave.

I'le give but one In≈øtance in that ≈øame Act of Uniformity, which requires all Clergy-men to give their a≈ø≈øent and con≈øent to all and every thing (for Truth) which is contained in the Common-prayer Book.

For ought they know, they may command and enact that all Clergy-men ≈øhal a≈ø≈øent in their Judgments, and con≈øent in their Wills, to a palpable error, lie, or untruth; or el≈øe, take their choice, to ≈øtarve, lie down and die; for Farm they may not, Thra≈øh they cannot, and if they Beg, they are ≈øent to Bridewel.

And this is our very ca≈øe this day; We may not chu≈øe what Chapters for Le≈ø≈øons, what Collects, Epi≈øtles and Go≈øpels, we li≈øt to read, but mu≈øt read tho≈øe that are appointed for the day: And the la≈øt year they were all fal≈øly appointed, or el≈øe tho≈øe words in the Common-prayer Book are fal≈øe, that fixes and a≈øcertains Ea≈øter Sunday (the Aera, or beginning of the Account, whence all the Le≈ø≈øons, Collects, Epi≈øties and Go≈øpels, are computed, nominated, and appointed).

I can give ≈øeveral other in≈øtances of our irrational Doctrine and Di≈øcipline, but I am loth to offend, let them even go on, they'l give me but little thanks for my pains already; but, I thank God, I do not find the fault, to expo≈øe it to ≈øhame, but to cure it, I know how: And, let me tell you, it requires ≈øome skill in the Cure, Why may not Lightning ≈øometime come from a black Cloud? and a dull By-≈øtander ≈øee better ≈øometime, than he that play? div.head: CHAP. III. Concerning Bi≈øhops.
div.p: WHat I am going to ≈øpeak concerning Bi≈øhops, may the more favourably be received, becau≈øe ≈øo contrary to ≈øelf-intere≈øt, the wor≈øt of evil Coun≈øellors.

But, it is a received Maxime,‚ÄîNo Bi≈øhop, no King: I know not who invented it, but it may be true, in ≈øome ≈øen≈øe; but it is fal≈øe, If it be meant ‚Äîno Rich Bi≈øhop, no King; for that the Rich Bi≈øhops were ≈øo Rich, that what with the Hank they got upon ≈øilly Mens Con≈øciences, and the Intere≈øt that their Lands, good Lea≈øes, and Dependencies, their Tenants, Servants, and Friends, they were ≈øo prevalent, when united, that, when our Kings have (≈øometimes) been ≈øo hardy and boid as to di≈øplea≈øe them, they have either taken the Crown from his Head, (as the Rich Bi≈øhop of winche≈øter unking'd his Brother King Stephen) on who≈øe Head that Nimrod of a Clergy-man had, without any right, clapt it on; and upon di≈øplea≈øure, the Bi≈øhop chiefly unking'd him again, and (in effect) ≈øpurn'd „Äà‚óä„Äâ off, as Pandolfus the Popes Nuncio, did the ‚Ä¢ rown off King John's Head, which ≈øay groveling at his Foot, whil≈øt the proud Prelat, put it on: and to ≈øhew the Eccle≈øia≈øtical In≈øolence of ≈øome Lawn-Sleeves, he up with his foot, and kick't it off from the Kings Head.
